word.entryDescription: a few
word.entryExample: I've brought a couple of sandwiches for us.

word.entryDescription: a meeting
word.entryExample: I'm having a get-together at my place. Can you come?

word.entryDescription: an indefinite but large amount of
word.entryExample: People used to eat a great deal of potatoes.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to a time after 12 midnight but before 12 midday
word.entryExample: I start work at 8 a.m.

word.entryDescription: to leave something or someone permanently
word.entryExample: His car was found abandoned in the car park at a motorway service station.

word.entryDescription: (plural 'abilities') the physical or mental power, or the skills or resources that you need to do something
word.entryExample: The ability to solve problems is a sign of how intelligent you are.

word.entryDescription: in a higher position than something else
word.entryExample: Put the picture above the fireplace.

word.entryDescription: to take in something which has come into contact
word.entryExample: Greenhouse gases absorb solar radiation and emit it to the earth's atmosphere as heat.

word.entryDescription: to take something that is offered, or agree to something
word.entryExample: I am very sorry, but we can't accept your invitation.

word.entryDescription: the opportunity to use or see something, or to enter a place, etc.
word.entryExample: It's crucial that young people get really good access to physical exercise.

word.entryDescription: extra items such as belts, bags, jewellery, hats, etc which are worn with regular clothes or carried
word.entryExample: What everyone remembers about the British Music Experience, however, are the clothes and accessories worn by the stars from over the years.

word.entryDescription: a crash involving any method of transport
word.entryExample: I had an accident and fell off my bike last night when a cat ran in front of me.
The song writer apologised for accidentally copying his music.

word.entryDescription: a room, house, etc in which to stay, live, etc
word.entryExample: Campervans are a popular way to save money on accommodation.

word.entryDescription: somebody who keeps or checks financial records
word.entryExample: Let's see, I could be an accountant, an architect, a doctor or a dentist.

word.entryDescription: correct or true without any mistakes
word.entryExample: Dad thinks I'll be a good accountant, like Mum, as I'm good at maths and very accurate.

word.entryDescription: to say that someone has done something bad before it has been proven
word.entryExample: He was accused, and later convicted of burglary and theft, and was sentenced to two years in prison.

word.entryDescription: to be in pain
word.entryExample: I couldn't walk properly and my back started to ache.

word.entryDescription: something important or difficult that you have had success in doing
word.entryExample: Finally, I enclose a copy of my CV so that you can see in more detail my achievements and skills.

word.entryDescription: the amount of acid in a substance
word.entryExample: Bacteria have several requirements to multiply: temperature, time, moisture and acidity (pH level).

word.entryDescription: past simple of 'act' – to play the part of a character in a film, play, etc
word.entryExample: Alex acted in the school play.

word.entryDescription: films or books where the main character gets into dangerous, often violent, situations
word.entryExample: My brother is really into action films, but I don't really like violence and fighting.

word.entryDescription: busy or involved in activities
word.entryExample: There's an information network for people who want to be active in supporting green issues.

word.entryDescription: somebody who performs in a film, drama programme, play, etc; often used to refer to a man or boy
word.entryExample: Who's your favourite actor?

word.entryDescription: in fact
word.entryExample: Later he said that even though the bear was very strong, it actually only scratched his arm once.

word.entryDescription: a kind of alternative medicine which involves pushing needles through the patient's skin
word.entryExample: Thanks to acupuncture, people have their pain relieved.

word.entryDescription: the number, street, town, etc where a house or building is
word.entryExample: Don't give your address to somebody you don't know.

word.entryDescription: (past form 'admitted') to agree, often unwillingly, that something is true
word.entryExample: She admitted at the interview that she was looking for a new coach.

word.entryDescription: difficult or complicated; high level
word.entryExample: I'm studying advanced level French, intermediate Spanish and elementary Chinese, which is for beginners.

word.entryDescription: a useful or appealing quality that something has
word.entryExample: Previous experience in the same role is an advantage.

word.entryDescription: an exciting experience often involving a journey
word.entryExample: They want to have a holiday with adventure.

word.entryDescription: British for 'advertisement' – a picture, a short film or words which try to make people buy a product or use a service
word.entryExample: I'm trying to work out what the employer is looking for from the advert.

word.entryDescription: to inform and persuade the public about something you want to sell
word.entryExample: Special offers are advertised in every shop window.

word.entryDescription: an opinion regarding what you should or should not do
word.entryExample: Emma wants some advice about what to try on.

word.entryDescription: to have an influence on someone or something
word.entryExample: How does the weather affect your mood?

word.entryDescription: to have enough money to buy or do something
word.entryExample: It's too expensive. I can't afford it.

word.entryDescription: feeling frightened or worried
word.entryExample: Emma isn't afraid of spiders.

word.entryDescription: a continent between the Mediterranean Sea, the Atlantic Ocean and the Indian Ocean
word.entryExample: Are there lions in Africa?

word.entryDescription: at a later time
word.entryExample: I do my homework after school.
After that, you turn the switch off and unplug the charger.

word.entryDescription: the part of the day between morning and evening
word.entryExample: In the afternoon we play sports.

word.entryDescription: one more time
word.entryExample: Can I see you again next Friday?

word.entryDescription: how old something or somebody is
word.entryExample: Fill in this form with your name and age.

word.entryDescription: an organisation or company providing a specific service
word.entryExample: She has just given her details to an online dating agency.

word.entryDescription: behaving in a threatening way
word.entryExample: Alcohol makes some people aggressive.

word.entryDescription: back in the past from the present time
word.entryExample: They were rescued by boat a few hours ago.

word.entryDescription: to have the same opinion as
word.entryExample: My mum might agree if your parents do.

word.entryDescription: the growing of plants and keeping of animals in order to produce food and goods
word.entryExample: The trees were also cut down to make space for agriculture.

word.entryDescription: a system used to make a building, room, etc cooler
word.entryExample: It's so hot this evening; we really need air conditioning to keep the house cool.

word.entryDescription: of such a construction that it has little or no leakage of air
word.entryExample: Passive houses are building developments which are well-insulated, almost air-tight to minimise energy loss, thanks to triple-glazed windows.
